children.subject: <md>Yup. 162 helped me grasp the core C concepts so I could transition to C++. Most of the difference is in the slightly modified syntax to handle objects and classes (like using ::). It's probably a better use of time to do a personal project after having taken a class like 162. Tbh maybe even 61c is enough if you paid attention to the C part</md>
161 is in C? I thought it was only in C for the first third then in python and Go for the rest? I'm taking the class over the summer so just wondering about it..

Cs 184 is in c++, but maybe take classes that are in C like 161 and 162 as the languages are similar and then with your advanced knowledge in C you can smoothly transition to C++ by reading a some highly rated textbook!

history.content: <md>C++ is an absolute monster of a language – you're not going to learn it through a course, especially since the only courses (that I know of at least)  here that even use C++ are CS184 and CS267. Out of curiosity _why_ do you want to learn C++? If you're prepping for an interview or something like that then ignore this, but if you're learning C++ because you want to do performance engineering, consider [learning Rust](https://www.rust-lang.org/learn) instead, which allows you to write extremely high-performance code, but has excellent modern tooling, a much more coherent design than C++, and memory safety without garbage collection. But if you're dead-set on C++, I personally don't know much in the way of more advanced resources (largely because I hate C++ and stopped using it as soon as I didn't have to anymore), but [A Tour of C++](https://www.stroustrup.com/tour2.html) is the defacto starting point if you have no prior experience with the language (you can find the PDF on libgen for free, or get it [through the library](https://oskicat.berkeley.edu/search~S1/?searchtype=X&searcharg=A+tour+of+C%2B%2B&searchscope=1&SORT=DZ&extended=0&SUBMIT=Search&searchlimits=&searchorigarg=tA+tour+of+C++) if you happen to be in Berkeley).</md>

children.subject:
If this is a feasible option for you, community college CS courses are also an option!

I don't know about all of the CCs, but the vast majority of the CS classes from mine were in C++ and they really came in handy when I took CS 184 :)

history.content: <md>If there's no good class to learn c++, what's the recommended way to self-study?</md>
history.subject: Recommended courses to learn c++ (if any)?
